questions.text: A 53 yr female presented to OPD with complaints of knee joint pain for the last 6 months. She adds that pain is aggravated mostly whenever she' sits after performing household work. On examination there was swelling around the knee joint and microscopic examination of synovial fluid after arthrocentesis revealed needle shaped crystals with negative birefringence. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gout Needle shaped crystals with negative birefringence points to Gout.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presented to OPD with pain in her right knee. The knee is swollen as well. The clinical image of the case is shown. Identify the disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Osteoarthritis knees Old female with pain & swelling in knee is case of genu varum because of osteoarthritis of the bone.

questions.text: A 6 year old girl presented in an emergency department with elbow pain' there is swelling in the elbow and hand, and she can't move the elbow due to pain, and is having numbness in the fingers/hand. Her pulse is also feeble. An X ray was performed. Identity the vessel at danger?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Brachial artery 1. In supra condylar fracture of humerus- the most common injury is ant interosseous nerve 2. In posterolateral displacement-ant interosseous nerve 3. In postero-medial displacement - ulnar nerve

questions.text: Five year old male child presents in your OPD with genu varum on X ray; osteopenia and pseudo fractures can be noticed. On blood investigations, there is decreased vitamin D and increased ALP. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteomalacia 1. If we see genu varum in:- (I) Adult = OA (II) Child = rickets 2. In the question, because rickets is not in the options so we will go with “childhood onset OSTEOMALACIA’

questions.text: A Patient presented to the emergency department after falling on an ' outstretched hand. On examination, dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What can be a probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Colles' fracture Falling on outstretched hard-dinner fork deformity = Colle’s fracture.

questions.text: Identify the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Genu Valgum If both legs turning inside = genu varum If one leg turning outside = genu valgum Here, in the image, we can also see intermalleolar distance increases and knocking = ∴ genu valgum

questions.text: A 20 year old male presented to ortho OPD with chronic pain and swelling palpable in the knee. An Xray was performed given below. Identify the pathology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteochondroma Here we can see a bony stalk with cartilaginous cap’ with involvement of distal femur. So we are dealing with osteochondroma or exostosis.

questions.text: A 20 year old male with pain lateral side of his hand. An Xray was performed. Identify the Disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Enchondroma Enchondroma- Hand & feet most commonly involved Benign bone condition seen in meta-phalanges

questions.text: A 3 year old baby is presented to the OPD by his worried parents with the following complaint. How would you manage the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Postero-medial Soft Tissue ReleasePostero-medial soft tissue release soft tissue release because it is a small child. 0-1 yr = manipulation & casting 1-5 yr = PMSTR > 3 yr = Bony Sx >10 yr = triple arthrodesis

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with pain and swelling in his wrist. The X-ray is given below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Giant Cell Tumor Geographical destruction + soap bubble app + age > 18 $ Very classical for GCT (Gaint Cell Tumor)

questions.text: What is the treatment for the fracture given in the image?
A patient comes to OPD with c/o pain swelling in right shoulder. Fracture clavicle is suspected, which is the most common site of fracture clavicle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Junction of lateral 1/3rd and medial 2/3rd Here they have clearly asked the m/c site for fracture = junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd.

questions.text: What would be the probable diagnosis in the given X ray image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pott's spine

questions.text: A patient falls on an out-stretched hand. For management the doctor ties a cast as given in the image. Which fracture the patient suffer from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scaphoid Fracture The thumb is covered here ∴ It is not a handshake cast but a glass holding cast for scaphoid fracture. Handshake cast is for colle’s fracture.

questions.text: An 80 year old female patient is brought to the casualty with a history of slip and fall in the bathroom. She is having pain in the left hip and is unable to walk. She has no history of osteoarthritis. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. X-ray findings are shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hemiarthroplasty Since the patient is more than 65 years of age, then hemiarthroplasty (bipolar prosthesis) is preferred only if acetabulum is normal (no osteoarthritis), otherwise total hip replacement is done.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Terrible triad of Elbow

questions.text: 8 year old sustained fracture around elbow 2 years ago and has difficulty in hanging school bag. Diagnosis?
In a patient with localised bone pain,exaggerated in night, relieved by intake of aspirin. What's the most likely diagnosis?
30 year old after RTA has kept limb in external rotation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior hip dislocation The diagnosis for a 30-year-old patient involved in a Road Traffic Accident (RTA) with a limb kept in external rotation is most likely B. Anterior hip dislocation. Here's a breakdown of why: A. Posterior hip dislocation: This is the most common type of hip dislocation. The affected limb typically presents in a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. Therefore, this is incorrect. B. Anterior hip dislocation: This type of dislocation, though less common than posterior, classically presents with the limb held in a position of flexion, abduction, and marked external rotation. This perfectly matches the "external rotation" described. C. Fracture neck femur (displaced): A displaced fracture of the femoral neck typically results in a shortened and externally rotated limb. While external rotation is present, the accompanying shortening is usually a very prominent feature. D. Intertrochanteric fracture femur: Similar to a displaced femoral neck fracture, an intertrochanteric fracture also typically presents with a shortened and externally rotated limb. These are more common in older individuals, but can occur in younger patients with high-energy trauma. Given that the primary described sign is "limb kept in external rotation" without explicit mention of shortening, and considering the mechanism of high-energy trauma in a 30-year-old, anterior hip dislocation presents with this specific and often fixed external rotation as its most characteristic deformity. While displaced fractures of the proximal femur also cause external rotation, the fixed, flexed and abducted posture with external rotation is very distinct for an anterior dislocation.

questions.text: In given case which nerve is injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The radial nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in mid-shaft fractures of the humerus, like the one shown in the X-ray. This is because of its close anatomical relationship with the humerus itself. As the radial nerve travels down the arm, it passes through the radial (or spiral) groove, which is located on the posterior surface of the mid-humerus. When a fracture occurs in this region, especially when the bone fragments shift or displace, the nerve can easily be compressed, stretched, or even torn. Injuries to the radial nerve often result in characteristic clinical signs. The most classic symptom is wrist drop, where the person is unable to extend their wrist or fingers due to paralysis of the extensor muscles in the forearm. Additionally, there may be sensory loss over the back of the hand, particularly in the area between the thumb and index finger. These signs are considered hallmarks of radial nerve injury. Unlike the median and ulnar nerves, which run more medially and anteriorly in the arm, or the axillary nerve which is more associated with shoulder injuries, the radial nerve’s position in the radial groove puts it directly in harm's way during mid-shaft humeral fractures. Therefore, in any clinical or radiological scenario involving a humeral shaft fracture, the radial nerve is the nerve most at risk, making option B the correct and most appropriate choice.

questions.text: Outstretched hand with fracture of anatomical snuff box which bone most likely to fracture?
Injury to :
Identify the image?
In given image. Which structure most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spinal Accessory Nerve The image shows asymmetry in the shoulders, specifically a drooping of the right shoulder and wasting/weakness of the trapezius muscle on the same side. This appearance is highly suggestive of spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) damage, which innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The trapezius muscle is responsible for elevating the shoulder (shrugging) and stabilizing the scapula. Damage to this nerve results in shoulder droop, difficulty elevating the scapula, and scapular winging that is more lateral compared to the classic medial winging of serratus anterior paralysis. The spinal accessory nerve is commonly injured during procedures like lymph node biopsies in the posterior triangle of the neck. A. Vagus nerve Incorrect. The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) innervates many internal structures such as the larynx, heart, and gastrointestinal tract, but not the trapezius or shoulder muscles. Damage to the vagus nerve would cause voice changes (hoarseness), difficulty swallowing, and autonomic disturbances, not the shoulder droop seen in the image. C. Long thoracic nerve of Bell Incorrect. This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, and damage causes medial scapular winging, especially noticeable when pushing against a wall. In the image, the scapula is drooping and slightly winged laterally, not medially lifted off the thoracic wall, ruling out this nerve. D. Suprascapular nerve Incorrect. The suprascapular nerve supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which are involved in initial arm abduction and external rotation, respectively. Injury leads to weakness in shoulder movement, but not the marked shoulder drooping and trapezius wasting seen here.

Identify the stage of TB Hip in a female with left leg Shortening?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3 (Stage III: Advanced Arthritis). In the progression of Tuberculosis of the Hip, shortening of the leg signifies significant destruction of the hip joint. Stage I (Synovitis) involves inflammation and may even show apparent lengthening. Stage II (Early Arthritis) shows some initial cartilage damage but true shortening is not typically pronounced. Stage III (Advanced Arthritis) is characterized by substantial destruction of the articular cartilage, femoral head, and/or acetabulum, leading to true shortening of the limb and marked restriction of movement. Stage IV involves gross destruction and often pathological subluxation or dislocation, resulting in even more severe shortening. Therefore, the presence of shortening indicates the disease has progressed to at least Stage III, where such deformity becomes clinically evident due to the underlying bone and cartilage loss.
